<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Peugeot</h1>
<div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content">
<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
Jump to: <a href="#mw-head">navigation</a>, <a href="#p-search">search</a>
</div>

<dd>
<dl>

<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:247px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_RCZ_(Facelift)_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht,_7._Dezember_2014,_Ratingen.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Peugeot_RCZ_%28Facelift%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_7._Dezember_2014%2C_Ratingen.jpg/245px-Peugeot_RCZ_%28Facelift%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_7._Dezember_2014%2C_Ratingen.jpg" width="245" height="114" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Peugeot_RCZ_%28Facelift%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_7._Dezember_2014%2C_Ratingen.jpg/368px-Peugeot_RCZ_%28Facelift%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_7._Dezember_2014%2C_Ratingen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Peugeot_RCZ_%28Facelift%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_7._Dezember_2014%2C_Ratingen.jpg/490px-Peugeot_RCZ_%28Facelift%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_7._Dezember_2014%2C_Ratingen.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3497" data-file-height="1632" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_RCZ_(Facelift)_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht,_7._Dezember_2014,_Ratingen.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_RCZ" title="Peugeot RCZ">Peugeot RCZ</a> won five years in a row the <i>Diesel Car magazine</i> 'Sports Car of the Year'<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> and the <i>Top Gear</i> 2010 Coupé of the Year<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup></div>
</div>
</div>
<p><b>Peugeot</b> (<span class="nowrap"><small><a href="/wiki/American_English" title="American English">US</a></small> <span class="IPA nopopups"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_English" title="Help:IPA for English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="'p' in 'pie'">p</span><span title="/uː/ long 'oo' in 'food'">uː</span><span title="/ˈ/ primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="/ʒ/ 's' in 'pleasure'">ʒ</span><span title="/oʊ/ long 'o' in 'code'">oʊ</span></span>/</a></span></span>; <span class="nowrap"><small><a href="/wiki/British_English" title="British English">UK</a></small> <span class="IPA nopopups"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_English" title="Help:IPA for English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/ primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'p' in 'pie'">p</span><span title="/ɜːr/ 'ur' in 'fur'">ɜːr</span><span title="/ʒ/ 's' in 'pleasure'">ʒ</span><span title="/oʊ/ long 'o' in 'code'">oʊ</span></span>/</a></span></span>; <small>French pronunciation:&#160;​</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA_for_French" title="Help:IPA for French">[pøʒo]</a></span>) is a <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">French</a> car manufacturer, part of <a href="/wiki/Groupe_PSA" title="Groupe PSA">Groupe PSA</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup></p>
<p>The family business that preceded the current Peugeot company was founded in 1810,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> and manufactured <a href="/wiki/Burr_mill" title="Burr mill">coffee mills</a> and bicycles. On 20 November 1858, Émile Peugeot applied for the lion <a href="/wiki/Trademark" title="Trademark">trademark</a>. Armand Peugeot built the company's first car, an unreliable <a href="/wiki/Steam_car" title="Steam car">steam tricycle</a>, in collaboration with <a href="/wiki/Leon_Serpollet" class="mw-redirect" title="Leon Serpollet">Leon Serpollet</a> in 1889; this was followed in 1890 by an <a href="/wiki/Internal_combustion" class="mw-redirect" title="Internal combustion">internal combustion</a> car with a <a href="/wiki/Panhard" title="Panhard">Panhard</a>-<a href="/wiki/Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft" title="Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft">Daimler</a> engine.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> Due to family discord, Armand Peugeot in 1896 founded the Société des Automobiles Peugeot.</p>
<p>The Peugeot company and family are originally from <a href="/wiki/Sochaux" title="Sochaux">Sochaux</a>, France. Peugeot retains a large manufacturing plant and <a href="/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_de_l%27Aventure_Peugeot" title="Musée de l'Aventure Peugeot">Peugeot museum</a> there. In February 2014, the shareholders agreed to a <a href="/wiki/Recapitalisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Recapitalisation">recapitalisation</a> plan, in which <a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Motors" class="mw-redirect" title="Dongfeng Motors">Dongfeng Motors</a> and the French government each bought a 14% stake in the company.<sup id="cite_ref-time_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nytfeb18_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytfeb18-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nytfeb20_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytfeb20-13">[13]</a></sup></p>
<p>Peugeot has received many international awards for its vehicles, including five <a href="/wiki/European_Car_of_the_Year" title="European Car of the Year">European Car of the Year</a> awards. In 2013 and 2014, Peugeot ranked the second lowest for average CO<sub>2</sub> emissions among generalist brands in Europe, the <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">Renault</a> car maker group being ranked first, with 114.9g CO<sub>2</sub>/km.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> Peugeot is known as a very reliable brand, citing how its 1950s and 1960s models are still running in Africa and Cuba in the 2010s, where Peugeot is called "the lion".<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup></p>
<p>Peugeot has been involved in motor sport for more than a century. <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Sport" title="Peugeot Sport">Peugeot Sport</a> won the <a href="/wiki/World_Rally_Championship" title="World Rally Championship">World Rally Championship</a> five times, the <a href="/wiki/Intercontinental_Le_Mans_Cup" title="Intercontinental Le Mans Cup">Intercontinental Le Mans Cup</a> twice (2010, 2011), surpassing Toyota and Audi, the <a href="/wiki/World_Sportscar_Championship" title="World Sportscar Championship">World Endurance Championship</a> twice (1992, 1993), and the <a href="/wiki/Intercontinental_Rally_Challenge" title="Intercontinental Rally Challenge">Intercontinental Rally Challenge Championship</a> three times. During the last year, Peugeot Sport has surpassed the record set in the ascent to <a href="/wiki/Pikes_Peak" title="Pikes Peak">Pikes Peak</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208 T16</a> driven by <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A9bastien_Loeb" title="Sébastien Loeb">Sébastien Loeb</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> and got a triple victory of the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208 GTi</a> in its class at the <a href="/wiki/24_Hours_N%C3%BCrburgring" title="24 Hours Nürburgring">24 Hours Nürburgring</a> race.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> In 2015, Peugeot returned to the <a href="/wiki/Dakar_Rally" title="Dakar Rally">Dakar Rally</a> after its four victories in the 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup></p>
<p></p>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-8"><a href="#Factories"><span class="tocnumber">2</span> <span class="toctext">Factories</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-9"><a href="#Vehicles"><span class="tocnumber">3</span> <span class="toctext">Vehicles</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-10"><a href="#Awards"><span class="tocnumber">3.1</span> <span class="toctext">Awards</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-11"><a href="#European_Car_of_the_Year"><span class="tocnumber">3.1.1</span> <span class="toctext">European Car of the Year</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-12"><a href="#Semperit_Irish_Car_of_the_Year_award"><span class="tocnumber">3.1.2</span> <span class="toctext">Semperit Irish Car of the Year award</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-13"><a href="#Car_of_the_Year_award_in_Italy"><span class="tocnumber">3.1.3</span> <span class="toctext">Car of the Year award in Italy</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-3 tocsection-14"><a href="#Car_of_the_Year_award_in_Spain"><span class="tocnumber">3.1.4</span> <span class="toctext">Car of the Year award in Spain</span></a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-15"><a href="#Numbers"><span class="tocnumber">3.2</span> <span class="toctext">Numbers</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-16"><a href="#Others"><span class="tocnumber">3.3</span> <span class="toctext">Others</span></a></li>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-18"><a href="#Motorsport"><span class="tocnumber">4</span> <span class="toctext">Motorsport</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-19"><a href="#Early"><span class="tocnumber">4.1</span> <span class="toctext">Early</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-20"><a href="#Rallying"><span class="tocnumber">4.2</span> <span class="toctext">Rallying</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-21"><a href="#Touring_car_racing"><span class="tocnumber">4.3</span> <span class="toctext">Touring car racing</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-22"><a href="#Sports_car_racing"><span class="tocnumber">4.4</span> <span class="toctext">Sports car racing</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-23"><a href="#Pike.27s_Peak_Hillclimb"><span class="tocnumber">4.5</span> <span class="toctext">Pike's Peak Hillclimb</span></a></li>

</li>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-28"><a href="#Peugeot_Avenue"><span class="tocnumber">6</span> <span class="toctext">Peugeot Avenue</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-29"><a href="#See_also"><span class="tocnumber">7</span> <span class="toctext">See also</span></a></li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-30"><a href="#References"><span class="tocnumber">8</span> <span class="toctext">References</span></a></li>

</ul>
</div>
<p></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: History">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_history">Early history</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Early history">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The Peugeot family of <a href="/wiki/Valentigney" title="Valentigney">Valentigney</a>, <a href="/wiki/Montb%C3%A9liard" title="Montbéliard">Montbéliard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Franche-Comt%C3%A9" title="Franche-Comté">Franche-Comté</a>, France, began in the manufacturing business in the 19th century. In 1842, they added production of coffee, pepper, and salt grinders.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> The company's entry into the vehicle market was by means of <a href="/wiki/Crinoline" title="Crinoline">crinoline</a> dresses, which used steel rods, leading to umbrella frames, saw blades, chisels, wire wheels, and bicycles.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Armand_Peugeot" title="Armand Peugeot">Armand Peugeot</a> introduced his "<i>Le Grand Bi</i>" <a href="/wiki/Penny-farthing" title="Penny-farthing">penny-farthing</a> in 1882, along with a range of other bicycles. The car company and bike company parted ways in 1926 but Peugeot bicycles continued to be built until very recently.</p>
<p>Armand Peugeot became interested in the automobile early on and, after meeting with <a href="/wiki/Gottlieb_Daimler" title="Gottlieb Daimler">Gottlieb Daimler</a> and others, was convinced of its viability. The first Peugeot automobile, a three-wheeled, <a href="/wiki/Steam_car" title="Steam car">steam-powered car</a> designed by <a href="/wiki/L%C3%A9on_Serpollet" title="Léon Serpollet">Léon Serpollet</a>, was produced in 1889; only four examples were made.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-21">[21]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Steam_power" class="mw-redirect" title="Steam power">Steam power</a> was heavy and bulky and required lengthy warmup times. In 1890, after meeting Daimler and <a href="/wiki/%C3%89mile_Levassor" title="Émile Levassor">Émile Levassor</a>, steam was abandoned in favour of a four-wheeled car with a petrol-fuelled <a href="/wiki/Internal_combustion_engine" title="Internal combustion engine">internal combustion engine</a> built by <a href="/wiki/Panhard" title="Panhard">Panhard</a> under Daimler licence. The car was more sophisticated than many of its contemporaries, with a three-point suspension and a sliding-gear transmission.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1683._22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1683.-22">[22]</a></sup> An example was sold to the young <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Santos-Dumont" title="Alberto Santos-Dumont">Alberto Santos-Dumont</a>, who exported it to Brazil.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup></p>
<p>More cars followed, 29 being built in 1892, 40 in 1894, 72 in 1895, 156 in 1898, and 300 in 1899.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_21-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-21">[21]</a></sup> These early models were given "type" numbers. Peugeot became the first manufacturer to fit rubber <a href="/wiki/Tire" title="Tire">tyres</a> (solid, rather than <a href="/wiki/Pneumatic_tire" class="mw-redirect" title="Pneumatic tire">pneumatic</a>) to a petrol-powered car.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2007)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></p>
<p>Peugeot was an early pioneer in motor racing, with <a href="/wiki/Albert_Lema%C3%AEtre" title="Albert Lemaître">Albert Lemaître</a> winning the world's first motor race, the <a href="/wiki/Paris%E2%80%93Rouen_(motor_race)" title="Paris–Rouen (motor race)">Paris–Rouen</a>, in a 3&#160;hp Peugeot. Five Peugeots qualified for the main event, and all finished. Lemaître finished 3 min 30 sec behind the Comte <a href="/wiki/Jules-Albert_de_Dion" title="Jules-Albert de Dion">de Dion</a> whose steam-powered car was ineligible for the official competition.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-24">[24]</a></sup> Three Peugeots were entered in the <a href="/wiki/Paris%E2%80%93Bordeaux%E2%80%93Paris" title="Paris–Bordeaux–Paris">Paris–Bordeaux–Paris</a>, where they were beaten by Panhard's car<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> (despite an average speed of 20.8&#160;km/h (12.9&#160;mph)<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-26">[26]</a></sup> and taking the 31,500 franc prize.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated4_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated4-26">[26]</a></sup> This also marked the debut of <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a> pneumatic tyres in racing,<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1684._27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1684.-27">[27]</a></sup> also on a Peugeot; they proved insufficiently durable.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated2_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated2-24">[24]</a></sup> Nevertheless, the vehicles were still very much <a href="/wiki/Horseless_carriage" title="Horseless carriage">horseless carriages</a> in appearance and were steered by a <a href="/wiki/Tiller" title="Tiller">tiller</a>.</p>
<p>In 1896, the first Peugeot engines were built; no longer were they reliant on Daimler. Designed by Rigoulot, the first engine was an 8&#160;hp (6.0&#160;kW) horizontal twin fitted to the back of the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Type_15" title="Peugeot Type 15">Type 15</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1684._27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1684.-27">[27]</a></sup> It also served as the basis of a nearly exact copy produced by <a href="/wiki/Rochet-Schneider" title="Rochet-Schneider">Rochet-Schneider</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1684._27-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1684.-27">[27]</a></sup> Further improvements followed: the engine moved to the front on the Type 48 and was soon under a <a href="/wiki/Hood_(vehicle)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hood (vehicle)">bonnet</a> at the front of the car, instead of hidden underneath; the steering wheel was adopted on the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Type_36" title="Peugeot Type 36">Type 36</a>; and they began to look more like the modern car.</p>
<p>Also in 1896, Armand Peugeot broke away from Les Fils de Peugeot Frères to form his own company, Société Anonyme des Automobiles Peugeot, building a new factory at <a href="/wiki/Arrondissement_of_Montb%C3%A9liard" title="Arrondissement of Montbéliard">Audincourt</a> to focus entirely on cars.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1684._27-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1684.-27">[27]</a></sup> In 1899, sales hit 300; total car sales for all of France that year were 1,200.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1684._27-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1684.-27">[27]</a></sup> The same year, Lemaître won the Nice-Castellane-Nice Rally in a special 5,850&#160;cc (357&#160;cu&#160;in) 20&#160;hp (14.9&#160;kW) racer.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1684._27-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1684.-27">[27]</a></sup></p>
<p>At the 1901 <a href="/wiki/Paris_Salon" class="mw-redirect" title="Paris Salon">Paris Salon</a>, Peugeot debuted a tiny shaft-driven 652&#160;cc (40&#160;cu&#160;in) 5&#160;hp (3.7&#160;kW) one-cylinder, dubbed "<i>Bébé</i>" ("baby"), and shed its conservative image, becoming a style leader.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1685._28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1685.-28">[28]</a></sup> After placing 19th in the 1902 Paris-Vienna Rally with a 50&#160;hp (37.3&#160;kW) 11,322&#160;cc (691&#160;cu&#160;in) racer, and failing to finish with two similar cars, Peugeot quit racing.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1685._28-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1685.-28">[28]</a></sup></p>
<p>Peugeot added motorcycles to its range in 1903, and they have been built under the Peugeot name ever since. By 1903, Peugeot produced half of the cars built in France, and they offered the 5&#160;hp (4&#160;kW) <i>Bébé</i>, a 6.5&#160;hp (4.8&#160;kW) four-seater, and an 8&#160;hp (6.0&#160;kW) and 12&#160;hp (8.9&#160;kW) resembling contemporary <a href="/wiki/Mercedes_(car)" class="mw-redirect" title="Mercedes (car)">Mercedes</a> models.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1685._28-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1685.-28">[28]</a></sup></p>
<p>The 1907 salon showed Peugeot's first six-cylinder, and marked <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tony_Huber&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tony Huber (page does not exist)">Tony Huber</a> joining as engine builder.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1685._28-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1685.-28">[28]</a></sup> By 1910, Peugeot's <a href="/wiki/Product_line" class="mw-redirect" title="Product line">product line</a> included a 1,149&#160;cc (70&#160;cu&#160;in) two-cylinder and six four-cylinders, of between two and six liters. In addition, a new factory opened the same year at Sochaux, which became the main plant in 1928.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup></p>
<p>A more famous name, <a href="/wiki/Ettore_Bugatti" title="Ettore Bugatti">Ettore Bugatti</a>, designed the new 850&#160;cc (52&#160;cu&#160;in) four-cylinder <i>Bébé</i> of 1912.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1685._28-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1685.-28">[28]</a></sup> The same year, Peugeot returned to racing with a team of three driver-engineers (a breed typical of the pioneer period, exemplified by <a href="/wiki/Enzo_Ferrari" title="Enzo Ferrari">Enzo Ferrari</a> among others): <a href="/wiki/Jules_Goux" title="Jules Goux">Jules Goux</a> (graduate of <i>Arts et Metiers</i>, Paris), <a href="/wiki/Paul_Zuccarelli" title="Paul Zuccarelli">Paolo Zuccarelli</a> (formerly of <a href="/wiki/Hispano-Suiza" title="Hispano-Suiza">Hispano-Suiza</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Georges_Boillot" title="Georges Boillot">Georges Boillot</a> (collectively called <i>Les Charlatans</i>), with 26-year-old Swiss engineer <a href="/wiki/Ernest_Henry_(engineer)" title="Ernest Henry (engineer)">Ernest Henry</a> to make their ideas reality. The company decided <i>voiturette</i> (light car) racing was not enough, and chose to try <i>grandes épreuves</i> (grand touring). They did so with an engineering <i>tour de force</i>: a <a href="/wiki/Dual_overhead_camshaft" class="mw-redirect" title="Dual overhead camshaft">dual overhead camshaft</a> (DOHC) 7.6-liter four-cylinder (110x200 mm) with four valves per cylinder.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> It proved faster than other cars of its time, and Boillot won the 1912 French Grand Prix at an average of 68.45&#160;mph (110.2&#160;km/h), despite losing third gear and taking a 20-minute pit stop.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-31">[31]</a></sup> In May 1913, Goux took one to <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_500" title="Indianapolis 500">Indianapolis</a>, and won at an average of 75.92&#160;mph (122.2&#160;km/h), recording straightaway speeds of 93.5&#160;mph (150.5&#160;km/h).<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_31-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-31">[31]</a></sup> making Peugeot the first non-American-based auto company to win at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. In 1914, Boillot's 3-liter L5 set a new Indy lap record of 99.5&#160;mph (160.1&#160;km/h), and Duray placed second (beaten by ex-Peugeot ace <a href="/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Thomas_(auto_racing)" class="mw-redirect" title="René Thomas (auto racing)">René Thomas</a> in a 6,235&#160;cc (380&#160;cu&#160;in) <a href="/wiki/Delage" title="Delage">Delage</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated5_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated5-32">[32]</a></sup> Another (driven by Boillot's brother, <a href="/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Boillot" title="André Boillot">André</a>) placed in 1915; similar models won in 1916 (<a href="/wiki/Dario_Resta" title="Dario Resta">Dario Resta</a>) and 1919 (<a href="/wiki/Howdy_Wilcox" title="Howdy Wilcox">Howdy Wilcox</a>).</p>
<p>For the 1913 <a href="/wiki/French_Grand_Prix" title="French Grand Prix">French Grand Prix</a>, an improved L5 (with 5,655&#160;cc (345&#160;cu&#160;in) engine) was produced with a pioneering ballbearing <a href="/wiki/Crankshaft" title="Crankshaft">crankshaft</a>, gear-driven camshafts, and <a href="/wiki/Dry_sump" title="Dry sump">dry sump</a> lubrication, all of which soon became standard on racing cars; Zuccarelli was killed during testing on public roads,<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated3_31-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated3-31">[31]</a></sup> but Boillot easily won the event, making him (and Peugeot) the race's first double winner.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated5_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated5-32">[32]</a></sup> For the 1914 French GP, Peugeot was overmatched by <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_in_motorsport" title="Mercedes-Benz in motorsport">Mercedes</a>, and despite a new innovation, four-wheel brakes (against the Mercedes' rear-only), Georges proved unable to match them and the car broke down.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated5_32-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated5-32">[32]</a></sup> (Surprisingly, a 1914 model turned a 103&#160;mph (165.8&#160;km/h) lap in practice at Indy in 1949, yet it failed to qualify.)<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1690._33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1690.-33">[33]</a></sup> Peugeot was more fortunate in 1915, winning at the French GP and <a href="/wiki/Vanderbilt_Cup" title="Vanderbilt Cup">Vanderbilt Cup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1690._33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1690.-33">[33]</a></sup></p>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a>, Peugeot turned largely to arms production, becoming a major manufacturer of arms and military vehicles, from armoured cars and bicycles to shells.</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">

<div style="margin:30px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_Phaeton_139A.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Peugeot_Phaeton_139A.JPG/120px-Peugeot_Phaeton_139A.JPG" width="120" height="90" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Peugeot_Phaeton_139A.JPG/180px-Peugeot_Phaeton_139A.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Peugeot_Phaeton_139A.JPG/240px-Peugeot_Phaeton_139A.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Peugeot, model Phaeton 139A, 1913</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Interwar_years">Interwar years</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Interwar years">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EM_Peugeot_201_5821.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/EM_Peugeot_201_5821.jpg/220px-EM_Peugeot_201_5821.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/EM_Peugeot_201_5821.jpg/330px-EM_Peugeot_201_5821.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/22/EM_Peugeot_201_5821.jpg/440px-EM_Peugeot_201_5821.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:EM_Peugeot_201_5821.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_201" title="Peugeot 201">Peugeot 201</a></div>
</div>
</div>
<p>After the war, car production resumed in earnest. Racing continued as well, with Boillot entering the 1919 <a href="/wiki/Targa_Florio" title="Targa Florio">Targa Florio</a> in a 2.5-liter (150-in<sup>3</sup>) car designed for an event pre-empted by World War I; the car had 200,000&#160;km (120,000&#160;mi) on it, yet Boillot won with an impressive drive (the best of his career)<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1690._33-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1690.-33">[33]</a></sup> Peugeots in his hands were third in the 1925 Targa, first in the 1922 and 1925 <a href="/wiki/Coppa_Florio" title="Coppa Florio">Coppa Florios</a>, first in the 1923 and 1925 Touring Car Grands Prix, and first at the 1926 <a href="/wiki/Spa_24_Hours" title="Spa 24 Hours">Spa 24 Hours</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1690._33-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1690.-33">[33]</a></sup> Peugeot introduced a five-valve-per-cylinder, triple-overhead-cam engine for the Grand Prix, conceived by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marcel_Gremillon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marcel Gremillon (page does not exist)">Marcel Gremillon</a> (who had criticised the early DOHC), but the engine was a failure.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1690._33-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1690.-33">[33]</a></sup></p>
<p>The same year, Peugeot debuted 10&#160;hp (7.5&#160;kW) and 14&#160;hp (10.4&#160;kW) fours, the larger based on the <b>Type 153</b>, and a 6-liter 25&#160;hp (19&#160;kW) <a href="/wiki/Sleeve_valve" title="Sleeve valve">sleeve valve</a> six, as well as a new <a href="/wiki/Cyclecar" title="Cyclecar">cyclecar</a>, <i>La Quadrilette</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1690._33-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1690.-33">[33]</a></sup></p>
<p>During the 1920s, Peugeot expanded, in 1926 splitting the cycle (pedal and motor) business off to form Cycles Peugeot, the consistently profitable cycle division seeking to free itself from the rather more cyclical auto business, and taking over the defunct <a href="/wiki/Bellanger" title="Bellanger">Bellanger</a> and <a href="/wiki/De_Dion-Bouton" title="De Dion-Bouton">De Dion</a> companies in 1927.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1690._33-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1690.-33">[33]</a></sup> In 1928, the <b>Type 183</b> was introduced.</p>
<div style="float: right; margin: 0 0 0.5em 1em; width: 30.5em; text-align: right; font-size: 0.86em; font-family: lucida grande, sans-serif; line-height: normal;">
<div style="border:1px solid #999; background:#fff; text-align:left; padding:1em; text-align:left;"><i>Peugeot Sochaux production (units):</i>
<dl>
<dd>
<dl>
<dd>
<dl>
<dd>
<ul>
<li>1930 43,303<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1932_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1932-34">[34]</a></sup></li>
<li>1931 33,322<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1932_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1932-34">[34]</a></sup></li>
<li>1932 28,317<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1932_34-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1932-34">[34]</a></sup></li>
</ul>
</dd>
</dl>
</dd>
</dl>
</dd>
</dl>
<dl>
<dd>Soon after the timely introduction of the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_201" title="Peugeot 201">Peugeot 201</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression" title="Great Depression">Great Depression</a> hit all the French auto-makers: Peugeot sales slumped, but the company survived.<sup id="cite_ref-Automobilia1932_34-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Automobilia1932-34">[34]</a></sup></dd>
</dl>
</div>
</div>
<p>New for 1929 was the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_201" title="Peugeot 201">Peugeot 201</a>, the cheapest car on the French market,<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1690._33-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1690.-33">[33]</a></sup> and the first to use the later Peugeot trademark (and registered as such)—three digits with a central zero. The 201 would get independent front suspension in 1931,<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Soon afterwards, the Depression hit; Peugeot sales decreased, but the company survived. The Peugeot system of using three digit names with a central 0 was introduced in 1929. The first digit has always signified the car's size and the final digit has indicated the generation of vehicle.</p>
<p>In 1933, attempting a revival of fortune, the company unveiled a new, aerodynamically styled range. In 1934, Peugeot introduced the <b>402 BL Éclipse Décapotable</b>, the first convertible with a <a href="/wiki/Retractable_hardtop" title="Retractable hardtop">retractable hardtop</a><sup id="cite_ref-Odin.2C_L.C._1939_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Odin.2C_L.C._1939-36">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup>&#160;— an idea followed later by the <a href="/wiki/Ford_Skyliner_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Ford Skyliner (disambiguation)">Ford Skyliner</a> in the 1950s and revived in the modern era by the <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_3000GT" class="mw-redirect" title="Mitsubishi 3000GT">Mitsubishi 3000GT Spyder</a> in 1995. More recently, many manufacturers have offered retractable hardtops, including Peugeot itself with the 206-cc.</p>
<p>Three models of the 1930s were the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_202" title="Peugeot 202">Peugeot 202</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_302" title="Peugeot 302">Peugeot 302</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_402" title="Peugeot 402">Peugeot 402</a>. These cars had curvaceous bodies, with headlights behind sloping grille bars, evidently inspired by the <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Airflow" title="Chrysler Airflow">Chrysler Airflow</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Odin.2C_L.C._1939_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Odin.2C_L.C._1939-36">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1693._39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1693.-39">[39]</a></sup> The 2.1-liter<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1693._39-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1693.-39">[39]</a></sup> 402 entered production in 1935 and was produced until the end of 1941, despite France's occupation by the Nazis. For 1936, the new Airflow-inspired 302 (which ran until 1938) and a 402-based large model, designed by Andrean, featured a vertical fin and bumper, with the first high-mounted taillight.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1693._39-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1693.-39">[39]</a></sup> The entry-level 202 was built in series from 1938 to 1942, and about 20 more examples were built from existing stocks of supplies in February 1945. The 202 lifted Peugeot's sales in 1939 to 52,796, just behind <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn" title="Citroën">Citroën</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1694._40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1694.-40">[40]</a></sup> Regular production began again in mid-1946, and lasted into 1949.</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">

</div>

</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
<div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">

</div>
<div class="gallerytext">

</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">

</div>
</div>
</li>
</ul>
<div class="thumb tright">

<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_403" title="Peugeot 403">Peugeot 403</a>, the sedan version of the cabriolet driven by the American TV detective <a href="/wiki/Columbo" title="Columbo">Columbo</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:1965_Peugeot_404_-_fvr-1_(4637118621).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/1965_Peugeot_404_-_fvr-1_%284637118621%29.jpg/220px-1965_Peugeot_404_-_fvr-1_%284637118621%29.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/1965_Peugeot_404_-_fvr-1_%284637118621%29.jpg/330px-1965_Peugeot_404_-_fvr-1_%284637118621%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/23/1965_Peugeot_404_-_fvr-1_%284637118621%29.jpg/440px-1965_Peugeot_404_-_fvr-1_%284637118621%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1280" data-file-height="853" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:1965_Peugeot_404_-_fvr-1_(4637118621).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_404" title="Peugeot 404">Peugeot 404</a>.</div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="After_World_War_II">After World War II</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: After World War II">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>In 1946,<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1694._40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1694.-40">[40]</a></sup> the company restarted car production with the 202, delivering 14,000 copies.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1693._39-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1693.-39">[39]</a></sup> In 1947, Peugeot introduced the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_203" title="Peugeot 203">Peugeot 203</a>, with coil springs, rack-and-pinion steering, and hydraulic brakes.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1694._40-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1694.-40">[40]</a></sup> The 203 set new Peugeot sales records, remaining in production until 1960.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1693._39-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1693.-39">[39]</a></sup></p>
<p>Peugeot took over <a href="/wiki/Chenard-Walcker" title="Chenard-Walcker">Chenard-Walcker</a> in 1950, having already been required to acquire a controlling interest in <a href="/wiki/Hotchkiss_(car)" title="Hotchkiss (car)">Hotchkiss</a> in 1942.<sup id="cite_ref-Darke.2C_p.1694._40-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Darke.2C_p.1694.-40">[40]</a></sup> A popular model introduced in 1955 was the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_403" title="Peugeot 403">Peugeot 403</a>. With a 1.5-liter engine, it sold one million copies by the end of its production run in 1962, famously including one <a href="/wiki/Columbo#Car" title="Columbo">cabriolet/convertible driven by TV detective</a> <a href="/wiki/Columbo_(TV_series)" class="mw-redirect" title="Columbo (TV series)">Columbo</a>.</p>
<p>The company began selling cars in the United States in 1958, and in 1960 introduced the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_404" title="Peugeot 404">Peugeot 404</a>, which used a 1,618&#160;cc (99&#160;cu&#160;in) engine, tilted 45°. The 404 proved rugged enough to win the <a href="/wiki/East_African_Safari_Rally" class="mw-redirect" title="East African Safari Rally">East African Safari Rally</a>, in four of the six years between 1963 and 1968.</p>
<p>More models followed, many styled by <a href="/wiki/Pininfarina" title="Pininfarina">Pininfarina</a>, such as the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_504" title="Peugeot 504">504</a>, one of Peugeot's most distinctive models. Like many European manufacturers, collaboration with other firms increased; Peugeot worked with <a href="/wiki/Renault" title="Renault">Renault</a> from 1966 and <a href="/wiki/Volvo_Cars" title="Volvo Cars">Volvo</a> from 1972.</p>
<p>Several Peugeot models were assembled in Australia, commencing with the 203 in 1953.<sup id="cite_ref-Australia_41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Australia-41">[41]</a></sup> These were followed by 403, 404 and 504 models with Australian assembly ending with the 505 in the early 1980s.<sup id="cite_ref-Australia_41-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Australia-41">[41]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Takeover_of_Citro.C3.ABn_and_Chrysler_Europe">Takeover of Citroën and Chrysler Europe</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Takeover of Citroën and Chrysler Europe">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/PSA_Peugeot_Citro%C3%ABn" class="mw-redirect" title="PSA Peugeot Citroën">PSA Peugeot Citroën</a></div>
<p>In 1974, Peugeot bought a 30% share of Citroën, and took it over completely in 1975 after the French government gave large sums of money to the new company. Citroën was in financial trouble because it <a href="/wiki/Research" title="Research">developed</a> too many radical new models for its financial resources. Some of them, notably the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_SM" title="Citroën SM">Citroën SM</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Comotor" title="Comotor">Comotor</a> <a href="/wiki/Wankel_engine" title="Wankel engine">Wankel engine</a> venture proved unprofitable. Others, the <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_CX" title="Citroën CX">Citroën CX</a> and <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_GS" title="Citroën GS">Citroën GS</a> for example, proved very successful in the marketplace.</p>
<p>The joint parent company became the <a href="/wiki/PSA_Peugeot_Citro%C3%ABn" class="mw-redirect" title="PSA Peugeot Citroën">PSA</a> (Peugeot <a href="/wiki/Soci%C3%A9t%C3%A9_Anonyme" class="mw-redirect" title="Société Anonyme">Société Anonyme</a>) group, which aimed to keep separate identities for both the Peugeot and Citroën brands, while sharing engineering and technical resources. Peugeot thus briefly controlled the Italian <a href="/wiki/Maserati" title="Maserati">Maserati</a> marque, but disposed of it in May 1975.</p>
<p>The group then took over <a href="/wiki/Chrysler_Europe" title="Chrysler Europe">the European division</a> of <a href="/wiki/Chrysler" title="Chrysler">Chrysler</a> (which were formerly <a href="/wiki/Rootes_Group" title="Rootes Group">Rootes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Simca" title="Simca">Simca</a>), in 1978 as the American auto manufacturer struggled to survive. Soon, the whole Chrysler/Simca range was sold under the revived <a href="/wiki/Talbot" title="Talbot">Talbot</a> badge until production of Talbot-branded passenger cars was shelved in 1987 and on commercial vehicles in 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="1980s_and_1990s">1980s and 1990s</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: 1980s and 1990s">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Pug205gti_vorn.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Pug205gti_vorn.jpg/220px-Pug205gti_vorn.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Pug205gti_vorn.jpg/330px-Pug205gti_vorn.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Pug205gti_vorn.jpg/440px-Pug205gti_vorn.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Pug205gti_vorn.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Peugeot 205</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 1983, Peugeot launched the successful <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_205" title="Peugeot 205">Peugeot 205</a> supermini, which is largely credited for turning the company's fortunes around. The 205 was regularly the bestselling car in France, and was also very popular in other parts of Europe, including Britain, where sales regularly topped 50,000 a year by the late 1980s. It won plaudits for its styling, ride and handling. It remained on sale in many markets until 1998, overlapping with the introduction of the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_106" title="Peugeot 106">106</a> in 1991, and ceasing production at the launch of the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_206" title="Peugeot 206">206</a>, which also proved hugely popular across Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup></p>
<p>As part of the Guangzhou Peugeot Automobile Company (GPAC) joint venture, the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_504" title="Peugeot 504">Peugeot 504</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_505" title="Peugeot 505">505</a> were built in China from 1985 to 1997.</p>
<p>By 1987, the company had dropped the Talbot brand for passenger cars when it ceased production of the Simca-based Horizon, Alpine, and Solara models, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Talbot_Samba" title="Talbot Samba">Talbot Samba</a> supermini which was based on the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_104" title="Peugeot 104">Peugeot 104</a>. What was to be called the Talbot Arizona became the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_309" title="Peugeot 309">Peugeot 309</a>, with the former Rootes plant in <a href="/wiki/Ryton-on-Dunsmore" title="Ryton-on-Dunsmore">Ryton</a> and Simca plant in <a href="/wiki/Poissy" title="Poissy">Poissy</a> being turned over for Peugeot assembly. Producing Peugeots in Ryton was significant, as it signalled the first time Peugeots would be built in Britain. The 309 was the first Peugeot-badged <a href="/wiki/Hatchback" title="Hatchback">hatchback</a> of its size, and sold well across Europe. The 309's successor, the 306, was also built at Ryton.</p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_405" title="Peugeot 405">405</a> saloon was launched in 1987 to compete with the likes of the <a href="/wiki/Ford_Sierra" title="Ford Sierra">Ford Sierra</a>, and was voted <a href="/wiki/European_Car_of_the_Year" title="European Car of the Year">European Car of the Year</a>. This, too, was a very popular car across Europe, and continued to be available in Africa and Asia after it was replaced by the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_406" title="Peugeot 406">406</a> nearly a decade later. Production of the 405 in Europe was divided between Britain and France, although its 406 successor was only produced in France. The 106, Peugeot's entry-level model from 1991, was also produced solely in France.</p>
<p>The Talbot name survived for a little longer on commercial vehicles until 1992 before being shelved completely. As experienced by other European volume car makers, Peugeot's United States and Canadian sales faltered and finally became uneconomical, as the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_505" title="Peugeot 505">Peugeot 505</a> design aged. For a time, distribution in the Canadian market was handled by Chrysler. Several ideas to turn around sales in the United States, such as including the Peugeot 205 in its lineup, were considered but not pursued. In the early 1990s, the newly introduced <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_405" title="Peugeot 405">405</a> proved uncompetitive with domestic and import models in the same market segment, and sold less than 1,000 units. Total sales fell to 4,261 units in 1990 and 2,240 through July 1991, which caused the company to cease its U.S. and Canada operations after 33 years.</p>
<p>In 1997, just six years after pulling out of both United States and Canadian markets, Peugeot returned to Mexico after a 36-year absence, under the <a href="/wiki/Chile%E2%80%93Mexico_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="Chile–Mexico Free Trade Agreement">Chile–Mexico Free Trade Agreement</a>. Peugeot models (1992–present) cannot be bought or imported into the United States from Mexico.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2000s_to_present">2000s to present</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: 2000s to present">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_407_Coupe_2.7_HDi_2006_(15519269999).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Peugeot_407_Coupe_2.7_HDi_2006_%2815519269999%29.jpg/220px-Peugeot_407_Coupe_2.7_HDi_2006_%2815519269999%29.jpg" width="220" height="91" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Peugeot_407_Coupe_2.7_HDi_2006_%2815519269999%29.jpg/330px-Peugeot_407_Coupe_2.7_HDi_2006_%2815519269999%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Peugeot_407_Coupe_2.7_HDi_2006_%2815519269999%29.jpg/440px-Peugeot_407_Coupe_2.7_HDi_2006_%2815519269999%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2984" data-file-height="1232" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_407_Coupe_2.7_HDi_2006_(15519269999).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_407" title="Peugeot 407">Peugeot 407</a> coupé, 2006</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_3008_HDi_FAP_110_Allure_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht,_17._M%C3%A4rz_2012,_Ratingen.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Peugeot_3008_HDi_FAP_110_Allure_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_17._M%C3%A4rz_2012%2C_Ratingen.jpg/220px-Peugeot_3008_HDi_FAP_110_Allure_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_17._M%C3%A4rz_2012%2C_Ratingen.jpg" width="220" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Peugeot_3008_HDi_FAP_110_Allure_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_17._M%C3%A4rz_2012%2C_Ratingen.jpg/330px-Peugeot_3008_HDi_FAP_110_Allure_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_17._M%C3%A4rz_2012%2C_Ratingen.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Peugeot_3008_HDi_FAP_110_Allure_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_17._M%C3%A4rz_2012%2C_Ratingen.jpg/440px-Peugeot_3008_HDi_FAP_110_Allure_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_17._M%C3%A4rz_2012%2C_Ratingen.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3492" data-file-height="2072" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_3008_HDi_FAP_110_Allure_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht,_17._M%C3%A4rz_2012,_Ratingen.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_3008" title="Peugeot 3008">Peugeot 3008</a>, 2010 <a href="/wiki/Semperit_Irish_Car_of_the_Year" class="mw-redirect" title="Semperit Irish Car of the Year">Semperit Irish Car of the Year</a> and 2010 Car of the Year in Italy</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>On 18 April 2006, PSA Peugeot Citroën announced the closure of the Ryton manufacturing facility in <a href="/wiki/Coventry" title="Coventry">Coventry</a>, England. This announcement resulted in the loss of 2,300 jobs, as well as about 5,000 jobs in the supply chain. The plant produced its last <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_206" title="Peugeot 206">Peugeot 206</a> on 12 December 2006, and finally closed down in January 2007.</p>
<p>Peugeot is a long way from its ambitious target of selling 4 million units annually by the end of the decade. In 2008, its sales stayed below the 2 million mark. In mid-2009, "adverse market and industry conditions" were blamed for falls in sales and operating losses. Christian Streiff was replaced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philippe_Varin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philippe Varin (page does not exist)">Philippe Varin</a> (CEO) and Jean-Pierre Ploué (head of design) was transferred from his post at Citroën. In 2009, Peugeot returned to the Canadian market with the scooter brand only.</p>
<p>Peugeot still plans on developing new models to compete in segments where it currently does not compete. Collin claimed that the French automaker competed in 72% of market segments in 2007, but he wanted to get that figure up to 90%. Despite Peugeot's sportscar racing program, the company is not prepared to build a pure sportscar any more hardcore than the RC Z sports-coupe. It is also pursuing government funding to develop a diesel-hybrid <a href="/wiki/Drivetrain" title="Drivetrain">drivetrain</a>, which might be key to its expansion.</p>
<p>By 2010, Peugeot planned on pursuing new markets, mainly in China, Russia, and South America. In 2011 it decided to re-enter India after 14 years with a new factory at <a href="/wiki/Sanand" title="Sanand">Sanand</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gujarat" title="Gujarat">Gujarat</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup></p>
<p>Peugeot re-entered the Philippines in 2012 after having a short presence in 2005 with distribution done by the Alvarez Group.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup></p>
<p>In March 2012, <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a> purchased a 7% share in Peugeot for 320 million euros as part of a cooperation aimed at finding savings through joint purchasing and <a href="/wiki/Product_development" class="mw-redirect" title="Product development">product development</a>. In December 2013, GM sold its entire Peugeot stake, taking a loss of about 70 million euros.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup></p>
<p>In October 2013, Peugeot closed their production plant at <a href="/wiki/Aulnay-sous-Bois" title="Aulnay-sous-Bois">Aulnay-sous-Bois</a> as part of a <a href="/wiki/Restructuring" title="Restructuring">restructuring</a> plan to reduce overcapacity in the face of a shrinking domestic market.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> By December 2013, Chinese investors were rumoured to be potential investors.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> In February 2014, the Peugeot family agreed to give up control of the company by reducing its holdings from 25% to 14%. As part of this agreement, <a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Motors" class="mw-redirect" title="Dongfeng Motors">Dongfeng Motors</a> and the French government were each to buy 14% stakes in the company, creating three partners with equal voting rights.<sup id="cite_ref-time_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-time-11">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nytfeb18_12-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytfeb18-12">[12]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-nytfeb20_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytfeb20-13">[13]</a></sup> The board of directors was to be composed of six independent members, two representatives of each Dongfeng, the French state and the Peugeot family, and two members representing employees and employees shareholders.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> The French government took the view the deal did not require approval by Brussels as <a href="/wiki/European_Union_competition_law" title="European Union competition law">EU competition rules</a> do not count public investment in a company on the same terms as a private investor as state aid.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> The equity participation by Dongfeng expanded an already budding relationship with Peugeot. The pair at the time were jointly operating three car-manufacturing plants in China, with a capacity of producing 750,000 vehicles a year. In July 2014, the joint venture, <a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Peugeot-Citro%C3%ABn" title="Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën">Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën</a>, disclosed they were building a fourth factory in China in <a href="/wiki/Chengdu" title="Chengdu">Chengdu</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Sichuan" title="Sichuan">Sichuan</a> Province, targeting the manufacture of 300,000 <a href="/wiki/Sport-utility_vehicle" class="mw-redirect" title="Sport-utility vehicle">sport-utility</a> and multipurpose vehicles a year, starting towards the end of 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-ChingduPeugeot_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ChingduPeugeot-51">[51]</a></sup> In January 2015, Indian multinational automotive giant <a href="/wiki/Mahindra_%26_Mahindra" title="Mahindra &amp; Mahindra">Mahindra &amp; Mahindra</a> purchased a major stake of 51% of Peugeot Motocycles for a price of 28 million euro.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Factories">Factories</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: Factories">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:362px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_Niederrhein_GmbH_Standort_Ratingen_20100529.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Peugeot_Niederrhein_GmbH_Standort_Ratingen_20100529.jpg/360px-Peugeot_Niederrhein_GmbH_Standort_Ratingen_20100529.jpg" width="360" height="86" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Peugeot_Niederrhein_GmbH_Standort_Ratingen_20100529.jpg/540px-Peugeot_Niederrhein_GmbH_Standort_Ratingen_20100529.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Peugeot_Niederrhein_GmbH_Standort_Ratingen_20100529.jpg/720px-Peugeot_Niederrhein_GmbH_Standort_Ratingen_20100529.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2153" data-file-height="513" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_Niederrhein_GmbH_Standort_Ratingen_20100529.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
A Peugeot dealership</div>
</div>
</div>
<dl>
<dt>PSA plants</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/PSA_Poissy_Plant" title="PSA Poissy Plant">PSA Poissy Plant</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208</a></li>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/PSA_Mulhouse_Plant" title="PSA Mulhouse Plant">PSA Mulhouse Plant</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_2008" title="Peugeot 2008">Peugeot 2008</a></li>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/PSA_Sochaux_Plant" title="PSA Sochaux Plant">PSA Sochaux Plant</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_308" title="Peugeot 308">Peugeot 308</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_3008" title="Peugeot 3008">Peugeot 3008</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_5008" title="Peugeot 5008">Peugeot 5008</a> (First Generation)</li>
<li>France (<a href="/wiki/PSA_Rennes_Plant" title="PSA Rennes Plant">PSA Rennes Plant</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_508" title="Peugeot 508">Peugeot 508</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_5008" title="Peugeot 5008">Peugeot 5008</a> (Second Generation)</li>
<li>Argentina (<a href="/wiki/Buenos_Aires" title="Buenos Aires">Buenos Aires</a>): 206 Plus (aka 207), 308, 408</li>
<li>Brazil (<a href="/wiki/Porto_Real" title="Porto Real">Porto Real</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_2008" title="Peugeot 2008">Peugeot 2008</a></li>
<li>Portugal (<a href="/wiki/Mangualde" title="Mangualde">Mangualde</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Partner" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot Partner">Peugeot Partner</a></li>
<li>Slovakia (<a href="/wiki/PSA_Trnava_Plant" title="PSA Trnava Plant">PSA Trnava Plant</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208</a></li>
<li>Spain (<a href="/wiki/Madrid" title="Madrid">Madrid</a>): 207 Plus, 207 CC</li>
<li>Spain (<a href="/wiki/PSA_Vigo_Plant" title="PSA Vigo Plant">PSA Vigo Plant</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Partner" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot Partner">Peugeot Partner</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_301" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot 301">Peugeot 301</a></li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Joint venture and outsourced plants</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li>Austria (<a href="/wiki/Graz" title="Graz">Graz</a> under contract by <a href="/wiki/Magna_Steyr" title="Magna Steyr">Magna Steyr</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_RCZ" title="Peugeot RCZ">Peugeot RCZ</a></li>
<li>China (<a href="/wiki/Wuhan" title="Wuhan">Wuhan</a>), joint venture <a href="/wiki/Dongfeng_Peugeot-Citro%C3%ABn" title="Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën">Dongfeng Peugeot-Citroën</a>: 206 Plus, 307, 308, 408, 508</li>
<li>Czech Republic (<a href="/wiki/Kol%C3%ADn" title="Kolín">Kolín</a>), <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Peugeot_Citro%C3%ABn_Automobile_Czech" title="Toyota Peugeot Citroën Automobile Czech">Toyota Peugeot Citroën Automobile Czech</a>: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_107" title="Peugeot 107">Peugeot 107</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_108" title="Peugeot 108">Peugeot 108</a></li>
<li>France (joint venture <a href="/wiki/Sevel_Nord" class="mw-redirect" title="Sevel Nord">Sevel Nord</a> near <a href="/wiki/Valenciennes" title="Valenciennes">Valenciennes</a>): <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Expert" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot Expert">Peugeot Expert</a></li>
<li>Iran (<a href="/wiki/Tehran" title="Tehran">Tehran</a>) <a href="/wiki/Iran_Khodro" title="Iran Khodro">Iran Khodro</a>: 206, 206 Sedan, 206 plus, 405, 406</li>
<li>Italy (<a href="/wiki/Val_di_Sangro" class="mw-redirect" title="Val di Sangro">Val di Sangro</a>), joint venture <a href="/wiki/Sevel" title="Sevel">Sevel</a>: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Boxer" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot Boxer">Peugeot Boxer</a></li>
<li>Japan, (<a href="/wiki/Kurashiki,_Okayama" title="Kurashiki, Okayama">Mizushima</a>) under contract by <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_Motors" title="Mitsubishi Motors">Mitsubishi Motors</a>: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_iOn" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot iOn">Peugeot iOn</a></li>
<li>Malaysia (<a href="/wiki/Gurun,_Kedah" title="Gurun, Kedah">Gurun</a>) assembly under contract to <a href="/wiki/Naza_Automotive_Manufacturing#Peugeot" title="Naza Automotive Manufacturing">Naza Automotive Manufacturing</a>: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">208</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_2008" title="Peugeot 2008">2008</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_308#Second_generation_.28T9.2C_2013.E2.80.93present.29" title="Peugeot 308">308</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_408#Second_generation_.282014-current.29" title="Peugeot 408">408</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_508" title="Peugeot 508">508</a></li>
<li>Netherlands <a href="/wiki/VDL_Nedcar" title="VDL Nedcar">NedCar</a> (former)&#160;: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_4007" title="Peugeot 4007">Peugeot 4007</a></li>
<li>Nigeria <a href="https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peugeot_Automobiles_Nigeria" class="extiw" title="fr:Peugeot Automobiles Nigeria">fr:Peugeot Automobiles Nigeria</a>&#160;: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_301" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot 301">Peugeot 301</a></li>
<li>Russia (<a href="/wiki/Kaluga" title="Kaluga">Kaluga</a>), joint venture Peugeot Citroën Mitsubishi Automotiv: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_4007" title="Peugeot 4007">Peugeot 4007</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_308" title="Peugeot 308">Peugeot 308</a> (First Generation)</li>
<li>Turkey (<a href="/wiki/Bursa" title="Bursa">Bursa</a>), under contract by <a href="/wiki/Tofa%C5%9F" title="Tofaş">Tofaş</a>: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Bipper" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot Bipper">Peugeot Bipper</a></li>
<li>Vietnam (<a href="/wiki/Ho_Chi_Minh_City" title="Ho Chi Minh City">Ho Chi Minh City</a>), joint venture THACO Group&#160;: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_408" title="Peugeot 408">Peugeot 408</a></li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Vehicles">Vehicles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: Vehicles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div class="thumb tmulti tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:224px;max-width:224px">
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_208_95_VTi_Active_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht,_5._Mai_2012,_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Peugeot_208_95_VTi_Active_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_5._Mai_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/220px-Peugeot_208_95_VTi_Active_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_5._Mai_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg" width="220" height="135" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Peugeot_208_95_VTi_Active_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_5._Mai_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/330px-Peugeot_208_95_VTi_Active_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_5._Mai_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Peugeot_208_95_VTi_Active_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_5._Mai_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/440px-Peugeot_208_95_VTi_Active_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_5._Mai_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3215" data-file-height="1967" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208</a>, Car of the Year in Italy and Spain</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_2008_82_VTi_Access_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht,_28._Mai_2014,_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Peugeot_2008_82_VTi_Access_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_28._Mai_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/220px-Peugeot_2008_82_VTi_Access_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_28._Mai_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg" width="220" height="131" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Peugeot_2008_82_VTi_Access_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_28._Mai_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/330px-Peugeot_2008_82_VTi_Access_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_28._Mai_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Peugeot_2008_82_VTi_Access_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_28._Mai_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/440px-Peugeot_2008_82_VTi_Access_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_28._Mai_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3496" data-file-height="2080" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_2008" title="Peugeot 2008">Peugeot 2008</a>, Car of the Year in Italy</div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_308_82_VTi_Active_(II)_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht,_4._Januar_2014,_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Peugeot_308_82_VTi_Active_%28II%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_4._Januar_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/220px-Peugeot_308_82_VTi_Active_%28II%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_4._Januar_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg" width="220" height="119" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Peugeot_308_82_VTi_Active_%28II%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_4._Januar_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/330px-Peugeot_308_82_VTi_Active_%28II%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_4._Januar_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/08/Peugeot_308_82_VTi_Active_%28II%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_4._Januar_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/440px-Peugeot_308_82_VTi_Active_%28II%29_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_4._Januar_2014%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3338" data-file-height="1810" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_308" title="Peugeot 308">Peugeot 308</a>, 2014 <a href="/wiki/European_Car_of_the_Year" title="European Car of the Year">Car of the year in Europe</a></div>
</div>
<div class="tsingle" style="margin:1px;width:222px;max-width:222px">
<div class="thumbimage"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_508_RXH_HYbrid4_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht,_15._Juli_2012,_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Peugeot_508_RXH_HYbrid4_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_15._Juli_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/220px-Peugeot_508_RXH_HYbrid4_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_15._Juli_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg" width="220" height="108" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Peugeot_508_RXH_HYbrid4_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_15._Juli_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/330px-Peugeot_508_RXH_HYbrid4_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_15._Juli_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Peugeot_508_RXH_HYbrid4_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_15._Juli_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg/440px-Peugeot_508_RXH_HYbrid4_%E2%80%93_Frontansicht%2C_15._Juli_2012%2C_D%C3%BCsseldorf.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3339" data-file-height="1635" /></a></div>
<div class="thumbcaption" style="clear:left"><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_508" title="Peugeot 508">Peugeot 508</a> SW <a href="/wiki/PSA_HYbrid4" title="PSA HYbrid4">HYbrid4</a></div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: Awards">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="European_Car_of_the_Year">European Car of the Year</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: European Car of the Year">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Peugeot has produced four winners of the <a href="/wiki/European_Car_of_the_Year" title="European Car of the Year">European Car of the Year</a> award.</p>
<div style="-moz-column-count:2; column-count:2; width:500px">
<ul>
<li><b>1969</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_504" title="Peugeot 504">Peugeot 504</a></li>
<li><b>1988</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_405" title="Peugeot 405">Peugeot 405</a></li>
<li><b>2002</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_307" title="Peugeot 307">Peugeot 307</a></li>
<li><b>2014</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_308" title="Peugeot 308">Peugeot 308</a></li>
<li><b>2017</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_3008" title="Peugeot 3008">Peugeot 3008</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<p>Four other Peugeot models got either second or third in the contest.</p>
<div style="-moz-column-count:2; column-count:2; width:500px">
<ul>
<li><b>1980</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_505" title="Peugeot 505">Peugeot 505</a></li>
<li><b>1984</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_205" title="Peugeot 205">Peugeot 205</a></li>
<li><b>1996</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_406" title="Peugeot 406">Peugeot 406</a></li>
<li><b>1999</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_206" title="Peugeot 206">Peugeot 206</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Semperit_Irish_Car_of_the_Year_award">Semperit Irish Car of the Year award</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: Semperit Irish Car of the Year award">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Peugeot has produced two <b>Car of the Year</b> award winners in Ireland since 1978. It is judged by the Irish Motoring Writers Association (IMWA).</p>
<ul>
<li><b>1997</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_406" title="Peugeot 406">Peugeot 406</a></li>
<li><b>2010</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_3008" title="Peugeot 3008">Peugeot 3008</a></li>
</ul>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Car_of_the_Year_award_in_Italy">Car of the Year award in Italy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: Car of the Year award in Italy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Peugeot S.A. has produced four "<i>Car of the Year</i> Auto Europa" award winners in Italy in 28 years, since 1987. "Auto Europa" is the prize awarded by the jury of the Italian Union of Automotive Journalists (UIGA), which annually celebrates the best car produced at least at 10,000 units in the 27 countries of the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>, and sold between September and August the previous year.</p>
<div style="-moz-column-count:2; column-count:2; width:500px">
<ul>
<li><b>2007</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_207" title="Peugeot 207">Peugeot 207</a><sup id="cite_ref-UIGA_oro_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UIGA_oro-53">[53]</a></sup></li>
<li><b>2010</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_3008" title="Peugeot 3008">Peugeot 3008</a><sup id="cite_ref-UIGA_oro_53-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UIGA_oro-53">[53]</a></sup></li>
<li><b>2013</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208</a><sup id="cite_ref-UIGA_oro_53-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UIGA_oro-53">[53]</a></sup></li>
<li><b>2014</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_2008" title="Peugeot 2008">Peugeot 2008</a><sup id="cite_ref-UIGA_oro_53-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UIGA_oro-53">[53]</a></sup></li>
<li><b>2015</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_308" title="Peugeot 308">Peugeot 308</a><sup id="cite_ref-UIGA_oro_53-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-UIGA_oro-53">[53]</a></sup></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Car_of_the_Year_award_in_Spain">Car of the Year award in Spain</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: Car of the Year award in Spain">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4>
<p>Peugeot S.A. has produced nine <b>Car of the year</b> award winners in Spain in 40 years, since 1974.</p>
<div style="-moz-column-count:3; column-count:3; width:750px">
<ul>
<li><b>1981</b> – <a href="/wiki/Talbot_Horizon" class="mw-redirect" title="Talbot Horizon">Talbot Horizon</a></li>
<li><b>1985</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_205" title="Peugeot 205">Peugeot 205</a></li>
<li><b>1999</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_206" title="Peugeot 206">Peugeot 206</a></li>
<li><b>2002</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_307" title="Peugeot 307">Peugeot 307</a></li>
<li><b>2005</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_407" title="Peugeot 407">Peugeot 407</a></li>
<li><b>2006</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_1007" title="Peugeot 1007">Peugeot 1007</a></li>
<li><b>2007</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_207" title="Peugeot 207">Peugeot 207</a></li>
<li><b>2012</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_508" title="Peugeot 508">Peugeot 508</a></li>
<li><b>2013</b> – <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208</a></li>
</ul>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Numbers">Numbers</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: Numbers">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_104" title="Peugeot 104">104</a> (1972), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_106" title="Peugeot 106">106</a> (1991), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_107" title="Peugeot 107">107</a> (2005), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_108" title="Peugeot 108">108</a> (2014)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_201" title="Peugeot 201">201</a> (1929), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_202" title="Peugeot 202">202</a> (1938), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_203" title="Peugeot 203">203</a> (1948), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_204" title="Peugeot 204">204</a> (1965), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_205" title="Peugeot 205">205</a> (1983), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_206" title="Peugeot 206">206</a> (1998), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_207" title="Peugeot 207">207</a> (2006), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">208</a> (2012)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_301_(1932%E2%80%9336)" title="Peugeot 301 (1932–36)">301</a> (1932), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_302" title="Peugeot 302">302</a> (1936), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_304" title="Peugeot 304">304</a> (1969), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_305" title="Peugeot 305">305</a> (1977), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_306" title="Peugeot 306">306</a> (1993), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_307" title="Peugeot 307">307</a> (2001), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_308" title="Peugeot 308">308</a> (2007), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_309" title="Peugeot 309">309</a> (1985), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_301" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot 301">301</a> (2012)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_401" title="Peugeot 401">401</a> (1934), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_402" title="Peugeot 402">402</a> (1935), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_403" title="Peugeot 403">403</a> (1955), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_404" title="Peugeot 404">404</a> (1960), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_405" title="Peugeot 405">405</a> (1987), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_406" title="Peugeot 406">406</a> (1995), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_407" title="Peugeot 407">407</a> (2004), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_408" title="Peugeot 408">408</a> (2010)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_504" title="Peugeot 504">504</a> (1968), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_505" title="Peugeot 505">505</a> (1979), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_508" title="Peugeot 508">508</a> (2010)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_601" title="Peugeot 601">601</a> (1934), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_604" title="Peugeot 604">604</a> (1975), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_605" title="Peugeot 605">605</a> (1989), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_607" title="Peugeot 607">607</a> (1999)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_806" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot 806">806</a> (1994), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_807" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot 807">807</a> (2002)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_905" title="Peugeot 905">905</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_908" title="Peugeot 908">908</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_1007" title="Peugeot 1007">1007</a> (2004), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_2008" title="Peugeot 2008">2008</a> (2013), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_3008" title="Peugeot 3008">3008</a> (2008), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_4007" title="Peugeot 4007">4007</a> (2007), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_4008" title="Peugeot 4008">4008</a> (2012), <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_5008" title="Peugeot 5008">5008</a> (2009)</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Others">Others</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Others">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<ul>
<li><a href="/wiki/Sevel_LAV" class="mw-redirect" title="Sevel LAV">Bipper</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Fiat_Ducato" title="Fiat Ducato">Boxer</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_DMA" title="Peugeot DMA">DMA/DMAH</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_D3_and_D4" title="Peugeot D3 and D4">D3/D3A</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_D3_and_D4" title="Peugeot D3 and D4">D4/D4A</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Expert" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot Expert">Expert</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Hoggar_(coup%C3%A9_utility)" title="Peugeot Hoggar (coupé utility)">Hoggar</a> (a pickup designed and manufactured in Brazil since 2010)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_J5" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot J5">J5</a>/<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_J7" title="Peugeot J7">J7</a>/<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_J9" title="Peugeot J9">J9</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_P4" title="Peugeot P4">P4</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Pars" title="Peugeot Pars">Pars</a> (also known as Persia)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Partner" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot Partner">Partner</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_RCZ" title="Peugeot RCZ">RCZ</a> (2010)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Type_15" title="Peugeot Type 15">Type 15</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_VLV" title="Peugeot VLV">VLV</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_iOn#France" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot iOn">iOn</a></li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Electric_and_hybrid_vehicles">Electric and hybrid vehicles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Electric and hybrid vehicles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:2012_Peugeot_3008_HYbrid4_Limited_Edition_UK_model.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/2012_Peugeot_3008_HYbrid4_Limited_Edition_UK_model.jpg/220px-2012_Peugeot_3008_HYbrid4_Limited_Edition_UK_model.jpg" width="220" height="132" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/2012_Peugeot_3008_HYbrid4_Limited_Edition_UK_model.jpg/330px-2012_Peugeot_3008_HYbrid4_Limited_Edition_UK_model.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/2012_Peugeot_3008_HYbrid4_Limited_Edition_UK_model.jpg/440px-2012_Peugeot_3008_HYbrid4_Limited_Edition_UK_model.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1706" data-file-height="1022" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:2012_Peugeot_3008_HYbrid4_Limited_Edition_UK_model.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_3008" title="Peugeot 3008">Peugeot 3008</a> <a href="/wiki/PSA_HYbrid4" title="PSA HYbrid4">HYbrid4</a>, UK model</div>
</div>
</div>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">See also: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_HYbrid4" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot HYbrid4">Peugeot HYbrid4</a></div>
