<p>Peugeot presented a new concept <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_electric" class="mw-redirect" title="Hybrid electric">hybrid electric</a> sports sedan at the 2008 <a href="/wiki/Paris_Motor_Show" title="Paris Motor Show">Paris Motor Show</a> called the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_RC_HYmotion4" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot RC HYmotion4">Peugeot RC HYmotion4</a>. Similar to the drivetrain model used in the upcoming <a href="/wiki/Chevrolet_Volt" title="Chevrolet Volt">Chevrolet Volt</a>, the RC concept promises the ability to run solely on electric power for extended periods, with a hybrid electric powertrain filling in the gaps when extra range is needed.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> The RC HYmotion4 includes a 70-kW electric motor at the front wheels.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> The Peugeot Prologue HYmotion4<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> was also shown at the <a href="/wiki/2008_Paris_Motor_Show" title="2008 Paris Motor Show">2008 Paris show</a> and is in many ways the opposite of the RC HYmotion4 concept. The Prologue puts the internal combustion engine up front and runs on diesel instead of gasoline, with the electric motor going at the back.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup></p>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_BB1" title="Peugeot BB1">Peugeot BB1</a> is an <a href="/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle" title="Battery electric vehicle">electric</a> <a href="/wiki/Concept_car" title="Concept car">concept car</a> with <a href="/wiki/In-wheel_motor" class="mw-redirect" title="In-wheel motor">in-wheel motors</a> in its rear wheels first shown in September 2009 at the <a href="/wiki/Frankfurt_Motor_Show" class="mw-redirect" title="Frankfurt Motor Show">Frankfurt Motor Show</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup></p>
<p>In 2010, Peugeot started selling the electric <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_iOn" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot iOn">Peugeot iOn</a>, a rebadged and revised version of the <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_i-MiEV" title="Mitsubishi i-MiEV">Mitsubishi i-MiEV</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup></p>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot_VELV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peugeot VELV (page does not exist)">Peugeot VELV</a> electric concept car was presented on 26 September 2011.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Motorsport">Motorsport</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Motorsport">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Sport" title="Peugeot Sport">Peugeot Sport</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early">Early</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Early">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jules_Goux_wins_Indianapolis.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Jules_Goux_wins_Indianapolis.jpg/220px-Jules_Goux_wins_Indianapolis.jpg" width="220" height="137" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Jules_Goux_wins_Indianapolis.jpg/330px-Jules_Goux_wins_Indianapolis.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Jules_Goux_wins_Indianapolis.jpg/440px-Jules_Goux_wins_Indianapolis.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5313" data-file-height="3316" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Jules_Goux_wins_Indianapolis.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Peugeot wins the 1913 Indianapolis 500</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Peugeot was involved in motorsport from the earliest days and entered five cars for the <a href="/wiki/Paris%E2%80%93Rouen_(motor_race)" title="Paris–Rouen (motor race)">Paris-Rouen</a> Trials in 1894 with one of them, driven by Lemaître, finishing second. These trials are usually regarded as the first motor sporting competition. Participation in a variety of events continued until <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, but in 1912, Peugeot made its most notable contribution to motor sporting history when one of their cars, driven by <a href="/wiki/Georges_Boillot" title="Georges Boillot">Georges Boillot</a>, won the <a href="/wiki/French_Grand_Prix" title="French Grand Prix">French Grand Prix</a> at Dieppe. This revolutionary car was powered by a <a href="/wiki/Straight-4" class="mw-redirect" title="Straight-4">straight-4</a> engine designed by Ernest Henry under the guidance of the technically knowledgeable racing drivers <a href="/wiki/Paul_Zuccarelli" title="Paul Zuccarelli">Paul Zuccarelli</a> and <a href="/wiki/Georges_Boillot" title="Georges Boillot">Georges Boillot</a>. The design was very influential for racing engines as it featured for the first time <a href="/wiki/DOHC" class="mw-redirect" title="DOHC">DOHC</a> and four valves per cylinder, providing for high engine speeds, a radical departure from previous racing engines which relied on huge displacement for power. In 1913, Peugeots of similar design to the 1912 Grand Prix car won the French Grand Prix at <a href="/wiki/Amiens" title="Amiens">Amiens</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_500" title="Indianapolis 500">Indianapolis 500</a>. When one of the Peugeot racers remained in the United States during World War I and parts could not be acquired from France for the 1914 season, owner <a href="/wiki/Bob_Burman" title="Bob Burman">Bob Burman</a> had it serviced in the shop of <a href="/wiki/Harry_Miller_(auto_racing)" title="Harry Miller (auto racing)">Harry Miller</a> by a young mechanic named <a href="/wiki/Fred_Offenhauser" title="Fred Offenhauser">Fred Offenhauser</a>. Their familiarity with the Peugeot engine was the basis of the famed Miller racing engine, which later developed into the <a href="/wiki/Offenhauser" title="Offenhauser">Offenhauser</a>.</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_405_T16_Dakar_Castle_Combe_2008_008.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Peugeot_405_T16_Dakar_Castle_Combe_2008_008.jpg/220px-Peugeot_405_T16_Dakar_Castle_Combe_2008_008.jpg" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Peugeot_405_T16_Dakar_Castle_Combe_2008_008.jpg/330px-Peugeot_405_T16_Dakar_Castle_Combe_2008_008.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Peugeot_405_T16_Dakar_Castle_Combe_2008_008.jpg/440px-Peugeot_405_T16_Dakar_Castle_Combe_2008_008.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2637" data-file-height="1771" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_405_T16_Dakar_Castle_Combe_2008_008.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Peugeot 405 Turbo 16, 1989 and 1990 winner of the Dakar Rally, with Ari Vatanen</div>
</div>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rallying">Rallying</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Rallying">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Sport" title="Peugeot Sport">Peugeot Sport</a> is one of the most successful winners in rallying, along with <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_World_Rally_Team" title="Citroën World Rally Team">Citroën Racing</a> (eight-time WRC winner), by winning five times the <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Rally_Championship_Constructors%27_Champions" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Rally Championship Constructors' Champions">World Rally Championship Manufacturer's Title</a> (1985-1986, 2000-2002), four times the <a href="/wiki/Dakar_Rally" title="Dakar Rally">Dakar Rally</a> (1987-1990), three times the <a href="/wiki/European_Rally_Championship" title="European Rally Championship">European Rally Championship</a> (2002-2003, 2008), three times the <a href="/wiki/Intercontinental_Rally_Challenge" title="Intercontinental Rally Challenge">Intercontinental Rally Challenge</a> (2007-2009).</p>
<p>Peugeot's <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">East Africa</a>n importers had a very impressive record in rallying in the 1960s; Nick Nowicki and Paddy Cliff won the East African Safari in 1963 with a Marshall's-entered 404 sedan. In 1966 and 1967, <a href="/wiki/Tanzania" title="Tanzania">Tanzania</a>'s Tanganyika Motors entered the winning 404 Injection sedan, piloted by the late Bert Shanlkand and Chris Rothwell. They might have won again in 1968, but while in second place, their engine blew and ultimately Nick Nowicki and Paddy Cliff upheld Peugeot's honour by winning the rally. Peugeot also won the Safari Rally in 1975 (Andersson in a 504 Injection sedan) and in 1978 (Nicolas in a 504 Coupé V6), both cars being factory team entries.</p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_205_Turbo_16_-_Race_Retro_2008_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Peugeot_205_Turbo_16_-_Race_Retro_2008_01.jpg/220px-Peugeot_205_Turbo_16_-_Race_Retro_2008_01.jpg" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Peugeot_205_Turbo_16_-_Race_Retro_2008_01.jpg/330px-Peugeot_205_Turbo_16_-_Race_Retro_2008_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Peugeot_205_Turbo_16_-_Race_Retro_2008_01.jpg/440px-Peugeot_205_Turbo_16_-_Race_Retro_2008_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_205_Turbo_16_-_Race_Retro_2008_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
Peugeot 205 Turbo 16, 1985 and 1986 winner of the World Rally Championship</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>Peugeot also had further success in international <a href="/wiki/Rallying" title="Rallying">rallying</a>, most notably in the <a href="/wiki/World_Rally_Championship" title="World Rally Championship">World Rally Championship</a> with the four-wheel-drive turbo-charged versions of the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_205" title="Peugeot 205">Peugeot 205</a>, and more recently the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_206" title="Peugeot 206">Peugeot 206</a>. In 1981, <a href="/wiki/Jean_Todt" title="Jean Todt">Jean Todt</a>, former co-driver for <a href="/wiki/Hannu_Mikkola" title="Hannu Mikkola">Hannu Mikkola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Timo_M%C3%A4kinen" title="Timo Mäkinen">Timo Mäkinen</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Guy_Fr%C3%A9quelin" title="Guy Fréquelin">Guy Fréquelin</a>, among others, was asked by Jean Boillot, the head of Automobiles Peugeot, to create a competition department for PSA Peugeot Citroën.<sup id="cite_ref-Todt_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Todt-60">[60]</a></sup> The resulting <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Sport" title="Peugeot Sport">Peugeot Talbot Sport</a>, established at <a href="/wiki/Bois_de_Boulogne" title="Bois de Boulogne">Bois de Boulogne</a> near <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> debuted its <a href="/wiki/Group_B" title="Group B">Group B</a> 205 Turbo 16 at the 1984 <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_Corse" title="Tour de Corse">Tour de Corse</a> in May, and took its first world rally win that same year at the <a href="/wiki/1000_Lakes_Rally" class="mw-redirect" title="1000 Lakes Rally">1000 Lakes Rally</a> in August, in the hands of <a href="/wiki/Ari_Vatanen" title="Ari Vatanen">Ari Vatanen</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> Excluding an endurance rally where Peugeot were not participating, Vatanen went on win five world rallies in a row.</p>
<p>Peugeot's domination continued in the <a href="/wiki/1985_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="1985 World Rally Championship season">1985 season</a>. Despite Vatanen's nearly fatal accident in <a href="/wiki/Rally_Argentina" title="Rally Argentina">Argentina</a>, in the middle of the season, his team-mate and compatriot <a href="/wiki/Timo_Salonen" title="Timo Salonen">Timo Salonen</a> led Peugeot to its first <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Rally_Championship_Drivers%27_Champions" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Rally Championship Drivers' Champions">drivers'</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Rally_Championship_Constructors%27_Champions" class="mw-redirect" title="List of World Rally Championship Constructors' Champions">manufacturers'</a> world championship titles, well ahead of <a href="/wiki/Audi" title="Audi">Audi</a> and their <a href="/wiki/Audi_Sport_Quattro" class="mw-redirect" title="Audi Sport Quattro">Audi Sport Quattro</a>. In the <a href="/wiki/1986_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="1986 World Rally Championship season">1986 season</a>, Vatanen's young replacement <a href="/wiki/Juha_Kankkunen" title="Juha Kankkunen">Juha Kankkunen</a> beat <a href="/wiki/Lancia" title="Lancia">Lancia</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Markku_Al%C3%A9n" title="Markku Alén">Markku Alén</a> to the drivers' title and Peugeot took its second manufacturers' title ahead of Lancia. Following <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Internationale_de_l%27Automobile" title="Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile">FIA</a>'s banning of Group B cars for <a href="/wiki/1987_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="1987 World Rally Championship season">1987</a>, in May after <a href="/wiki/Henri_Toivonen" title="Henri Toivonen">Henri Toivonen</a>'s fatal accident, Todt was outraged and even (unsuccessfully) pursued legal action against the federation.<sup id="cite_ref-Todt_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Todt-60">[60]</a></sup> Peugeot then switched to <a href="/wiki/Rally_raid" title="Rally raid">rally raids</a>. Using the 205 and a <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_405" title="Peugeot 405">405</a>, Peugeot won the Dakar Rally four times in a row from 1987 to 1990; three times with Vatanen and once with Kankkunen. In 2015 Peugeot again took part in the Rally Dakar with a newly constructed buggy. For the 2016 Paris-Dakar, Peugeot presented a new team of drivers including 9-time WRC-champion <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A9bastien_Loeb" title="Sébastien Loeb">Sébastien Loeb</a> and 12-time Dakar winner <a href="/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Peterhansel" title="Stéphane Peterhansel">Stéphane Peterhansel</a> who managed to win the 2016 edition for the Peugeot factory team in the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_2008" title="Peugeot 2008">Peugeot 2008</a> DKR</p>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mg2_peugeot.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Mg2_peugeot.jpg/220px-Mg2_peugeot.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Mg2_peugeot.jpg/330px-Mg2_peugeot.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Mg2_peugeot.jpg/440px-Mg2_peugeot.jpg 2x" data-file-width="768" data-file-height="512" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Mg2_peugeot.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Peugeot_206" title="Peugeot 206">Peugeot 206 WRC</a>, winner of the World Rally Championship from 2000 to 2002</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/1999_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="1999 World Rally Championship season">1999</a>, Peugeot returned to the World Rally Championship with the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_206_WRC" title="Peugeot 206 WRC">206 WRC</a>. The car was immediately competitive against such opposition as the <a href="/wiki/Subaru_Impreza_WRC" class="mw-redirect" title="Subaru Impreza WRC">Subaru Impreza WRC</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ford_Focus_WRC" class="mw-redirect" title="Ford Focus WRC">Ford Focus WRC</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Mitsubishi_Lancer_Evolution" title="Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution">Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution</a>. <a href="/wiki/Marcus_Gr%C3%B6nholm" title="Marcus Grönholm">Marcus Grönholm</a> gave the car its first win at the 2000 <a href="/wiki/Swedish_Rally" class="mw-redirect" title="Swedish Rally">Swedish Rally</a>, and Peugeot went on to win the manufacturers' title in their first full year since the return, and Grönholm the drivers' title in his first full WRC season. After successfully but narrowly defending their manufacturers' title in <a href="/wiki/2001_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2001 World Rally Championship season">2001</a>, Peugeot Sport dominated the <a href="/wiki/2002_World_Rally_Championship" title="2002 World Rally Championship">2002 season</a>, taking eight wins in the hands of Grönholm and <a href="/wiki/Gilles_Panizzi" title="Gilles Panizzi">Gilles Panizzi</a>. Grönholm also took the drivers' title. For the <a href="/wiki/2005_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2005 World Rally Championship season">2004 season</a>, Peugeot retired the 206 WRC in favour of the new <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_307_WRC" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot 307 WRC">307 WRC</a>. The 307 WRC did not match its predecessor in success, but Grönholm took three wins with the car, one in 2004 and two in <a href="/wiki/2005_World_Rally_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="2005 World Rally Championship season">2005</a>. PSA Peugeot Citroën withdrew Peugeot from the WRC after the 2005 season, while <a href="/wiki/Citro%C3%ABn_Total_World_Rally_Team" class="mw-redirect" title="Citroën Total World Rally Team">Citroën</a> took a sabbatical year in 2006 and returned for the next season. Meanwhile, Gronholm departed Peugeot when they quit at the end of 2005 to partner young compatriot <a href="/wiki/Mikko_Hirvonen" title="Mikko Hirvonen">Mikko Hirvonen</a> at <a href="/wiki/Ford_World_Rally_Team" title="Ford World Rally Team">Ford</a>.</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Peugeot_207" title="Peugeot 207">Peugeot 207</a> S2000, winner of the <a href="/wiki/Intercontinental_Rally_Challenge" title="Intercontinental Rally Challenge">Intercontinental Rally Challenge</a> from 2007 to 2009.</p>
<div class="mediaContainer" style="width:220px"><audio id="mwe_player_0" controls="" preload="none" style="width:220px" class="kskin" data-durationhint="10.653560090703" data-startoffset="0" data-mwtitle="Peugeot_207_S2000_(2010).ogg" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons">
<source src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/02/Peugeot_207_S2000_%282010%29.ogg" type="audio/ogg; codecs=&quot;vorbis&quot;" data-title="Original Ogg file (198 kbps)" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-width="0" data-height="0" data-bandwidth="197567" /></audio></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Touring_car_racing">Touring car racing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Touring car racing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Luciano_Burti_(5797860059).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Luciano_Burti_%285797860059%29.jpg/220px-Luciano_Burti_%285797860059%29.jpg" width="220" height="148" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Luciano_Burti_%285797860059%29.jpg/330px-Luciano_Burti_%285797860059%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Luciano_Burti_%285797860059%29.jpg/440px-Luciano_Burti_%285797860059%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2896" data-file-height="1944" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Luciano_Burti_(5797860059).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
In 2009 and 2011, Peugeot won the Stock Car V8 championship with Cacá Bueno (here Luciano Burti)</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In 2013, the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_208" title="Peugeot 208">Peugeot 208</a>GTi won a one-two-three at the <a href="/wiki/24_Hours_N%C3%BCrburgring" title="24 Hours Nürburgring">24 Hours Nürburgring</a> endurance race.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup></p>
<p>The Peugeot 306 GTi won the prestigious <a href="/wiki/Spa_24_hours" class="mw-redirect" title="Spa 24 hours">Spa 24 hours</a> endurance race in 1999 and 2000.</p>
<p>Peugeot has been racing successfully in the <a href="/wiki/Asian_Touring_Car_Series" title="Asian Touring Car Series">Asian Touring Car Series</a>, winning the 2000, 2001, and 2002 championships with the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_306" title="Peugeot 306">Peugeot 306</a> GTi.</p>
<p>Peugeot has been racing successfully in the <a href="/wiki/Stock_Car_Brasil" title="Stock Car Brasil">Stock Car Brasil</a> series since 2007 and won the 2008, 2009, and 2011 championships.</p>
<p>Peugeot won five times the <a href="/wiki/Danish_Touringcar_Championship" title="Danish Touringcar Championship">Danish Touringcar Championship</a>, with both the Peugeot 306 -winner in 1999, 2000 and 2001- and the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_307" title="Peugeot 307">Peugeot 307</a> winner in 2002 and 2003.</p>
<p>With his <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_406" title="Peugeot 406">Peugeot 406</a>, Laurent Aiello won the 1997 <a href="/wiki/Super_Tourenwagen_Cup" title="Super Tourenwagen Cup">Super Tourenwagen Cup</a> season.</p>
<p>Throughout the mid-1990s, the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_406" title="Peugeot 406">Peugeot 406</a> <a href="/wiki/Sedan_(car)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sedan (car)">saloon</a> (called a sedan in some countries) contested <a href="/wiki/Touring_car_racing" title="Touring car racing">touring car</a> championships across the world, enjoying success in <a href="/wiki/French_Touring_Car_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="French Touring Car Championship">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Super_Tourenwagen_Cup" title="Super Tourenwagen Cup">Germany</a> and Australia, yet failing to win a single race in the <a href="/wiki/British_Touring_Car_Championship" title="British Touring Car Championship">British Touring Car Championship</a> despite a number of podium finishes under the command of 1992 British Touring Car Champion <a href="/wiki/Tim_Harvey" title="Tim Harvey">Tim Harvey</a>. In Gran Turismo 2 the 406 saloon description sums its racing career up as "a competitive touring car which raced throughout Europe".</p>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tim_Harvey_BTCC_1996.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Tim_Harvey_BTCC_1996.jpg/220px-Tim_Harvey_BTCC_1996.jpg" width="220" height="153" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Tim_Harvey_BTCC_1996.jpg/330px-Tim_Harvey_BTCC_1996.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Tim_Harvey_BTCC_1996.jpg/440px-Tim_Harvey_BTCC_1996.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="837" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Tim_Harvey_BTCC_1996.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Tim_Harvey" title="Tim Harvey">Tim Harvey</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_406" title="Peugeot 406">406</a> during the <a href="/wiki/1996_British_Touring_Car_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="1996 British Touring Car Championship season">1996</a> <a href="/wiki/British_Touring_Car_Championship" title="British Touring Car Championship">BTCC</a> season</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>The British cars were initially prepared by Peugeot Sport; a team from the Peugeot UK factory in <a href="/wiki/Coventry" title="Coventry">Coventry</a> under the direction of team manager Mick Linford in 1996, with Total sponsorship. Peugeot Sport was not however a full professional race team akin to those of the competition, by now including Williams, Prodrive, Schnitzer and TWR; being as it was run from workshops within the Peugeot factory, largely by factory employees from 1992-1996, racing the 405 Mi16 from 1992-95. Peugeot therefore contracted Motor Sport Development (MSD; who had developed and run the Honda Accord in the <a href="/wiki/British_Touring_Car_Championship" title="British Touring Car Championship">BTCC</a> from 1995-1996) to build &amp; run the 406 for 1997-98, when they wore a distinctive green and gold-flame design in deference to new sponsor Esso.</p>
<p>Initially the 406's lack of success was blamed on suspension problems. During 1998 the 406 apparently lacked sufficient <a href="/wiki/Horsepower" title="Horsepower">horsepower</a> to compete with the front runners' Nissan Primeras and Honda Accords; this was mentioned during a particularly strong showing from Harvey's 406 at the Oulton Park BTCC meeting of 1998, when motorsport commentator <a href="/wiki/Charlie_Cox" title="Charlie Cox">Charlie Cox</a> stated "some people say (the 406) is down on power&#160;– you're kidding". During the first BTCC meeting at Silverstone in the same year, Cox mentions that MSD re-designed the 406 touring car "from the ground up". It was however widely reported in publications like the now-defunct 'Super Touring' magazine that it was the aero package primarily developed for longer, faster tracks in Germany and France that led to its success there, but hindered the 406 on the slower, twistier tracks of the UK.</p>
<p>In 2001, Peugeot entered three <a href="/wiki/BTC-T_Peugeot_406_Coup%C3%A9" title="BTC-T Peugeot 406 Coupé">BTC-T Peugeot 406 Coupés</a> into the British Touring Car Championship to compete with the dominant <a href="/wiki/Vauxhall_Astra" title="Vauxhall Astra">Vauxhall Astra</a> coupes. Unfortunately the 406 coupe was at the end of its <a href="/wiki/Product_lifecycle" title="Product lifecycle">product lifecycle</a> and was not competitive, despite some promise towards the end of the year, notably when Peugeot's Steve Soper led a race only to suffer engine failure in the last few laps. The 406 coupes were retired at the end of the following year and replaced with the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_307" title="Peugeot 307">Peugeot 307</a>—again, uncompetitively—in 2003. Alongside the BTC-C 406's; two works-supported 306 GTis were also raced in the BTC-P (Production) class by Simon Harrison and Roger Moen, with Harrison emerging class champion.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports_car_racing">Sports car racing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Sports car racing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_908_2007.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Peugeot_908_2007.jpg/220px-Peugeot_908_2007.jpg" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Peugeot_908_2007.jpg/330px-Peugeot_908_2007.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Peugeot_908_2007.jpg/440px-Peugeot_908_2007.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2750" data-file-height="1842" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_908_2007.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
The <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_908_HDi_FAP" title="Peugeot 908 HDi FAP">908 HDi FAP</a> <a href="/wiki/Sports_prototype" title="Sports prototype">sports prototype</a>, driven by <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Villeneuve" title="Jacques Villeneuve">Jacques Villeneuve</a> in 2007</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>In the 1990s the company competed in <a href="/wiki/Endurance_racing_(motorsport)" title="Endurance racing (motorsport)">endurance racing</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/World_Sportscar_Championship" title="World Sportscar Championship">World Sportscar Championship</a> and the <a href="/wiki/24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="24 Hours of Le Mans">24 Hours of Le Mans</a> race with the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_905" title="Peugeot 905">905</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Sports_car_racing" title="Sports car racing">sportscar</a> team was established at <a href="/wiki/V%C3%A9lizy-Villacoublay" title="Vélizy-Villacoublay">Vélizy-Villacoublay</a>, France.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> After early problems with reliability and <a href="/wiki/Aerodynamics" title="Aerodynamics">aerodynamics</a>, the 905 was successful in the <a href="/wiki/World_Sportscar_Championship" title="World Sportscar Championship">World Sportscar Championship</a>, winning eight of the 14 races across the <a href="/wiki/1991_World_Sportscar_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="1991 World Sportscar Championship season">1991</a> and <a href="/wiki/1992_World_Sportscar_Championship_season" class="mw-redirect" title="1992 World Sportscar Championship season">1992 seasons</a> and winning the team and driver titles in 1992. Peugeot also won the 24 Hours of Le Mans in <a href="/wiki/1992_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="1992 24 Hours of Le Mans">1992</a> and <a href="/wiki/1993_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="1993 24 Hours of Le Mans">1993</a>.</p>
<p>Peugeot returned to sportscar racing and Le Mans in 2007 with the diesel-powered <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_908_HDi_FAP" title="Peugeot 908 HDi FAP">Peugeot 908 HDi FAP</a>. At the <a href="/wiki/2007_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="2007 24 Hours of Le Mans">2007 24 Hours of Le Mans</a>, <a href="/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Sarrazin" title="Stéphane Sarrazin">Stéphane Sarrazin</a> secured <a href="/wiki/Pole_position" title="Pole position">pole position</a> but the 908s proved unreliable and ceded victory to <a href="/wiki/Audi" title="Audi">Audi</a>. In <a href="/wiki/2008_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="2008 24 Hours of Le Mans">2008</a>, the Sarrazin again earned a pole position but Audi prevailed once again. For the <a href="/wiki/2009_24_Hours_of_Le_Mans" title="2009 24 Hours of Le Mans">2009 24 Hours of Le Mans</a>, the Peugeot 908 HDi FAPs finished first and second overall, led by drivers <a href="/wiki/Marc_Gen%C3%A9" title="Marc Gené">Marc Gené</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Brabham" title="David Brabham">David Brabham</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Wurz" title="Alexander Wurz">Alexander Wurz</a>.</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pike.27s_Peak_Hillclimb">Pike's Peak Hillclimb</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Pike's Peak Hillclimb">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft">
<div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_405_T-16_GR_Pikes_Peak_-_Flickr_-_andrewbasterfield.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Peugeot_405_T-16_GR_Pikes_Peak_-_Flickr_-_andrewbasterfield.jpg/220px-Peugeot_405_T-16_GR_Pikes_Peak_-_Flickr_-_andrewbasterfield.jpg" width="220" height="176" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Peugeot_405_T-16_GR_Pikes_Peak_-_Flickr_-_andrewbasterfield.jpg/330px-Peugeot_405_T-16_GR_Pikes_Peak_-_Flickr_-_andrewbasterfield.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e8/Peugeot_405_T-16_GR_Pikes_Peak_-_Flickr_-_andrewbasterfield.jpg/440px-Peugeot_405_T-16_GR_Pikes_Peak_-_Flickr_-_andrewbasterfield.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3580" data-file-height="2864" /></a>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<div class="magnify"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_405_T-16_GR_Pikes_Peak_-_Flickr_-_andrewbasterfield.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a></div>
<a href="/wiki/Ari_Vatanen" title="Ari Vatanen">Ari Vatanen</a>'s Pikes Peak Peugeot 405</div>
</div>
</div>
<p>After <a href="/wiki/Ari_Vatanen" title="Ari Vatanen">Ari Vatanen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bobby_Unser" title="Bobby Unser">Bobby Unser</a>, in the late 1980s, won the <a href="/wiki/Pikes_Peak_International_Hill_Climb" title="Pikes Peak International Hill Climb">Pikes Peak International Hill Climb</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Sport" title="Peugeot Sport">Peugeot Sport</a> and <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A9bastien_Loeb" title="Sébastien Loeb">Sébastien Loeb</a> decided to unite their respective strengths and go for it. The Ari Vatanen performance won several awards with the "Climb Dance" films (Grand Prix du film de Chamonix 1990, Gold Award at International Film Festival in Houston, Silver Screen of the US Industrial Film &amp; Video Festival in Chicago, 1990 Prix spécial du Jury at the Festival International du Film d'aventure in Val d'Isère).<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup></p>
<p>In April 2013, a 208 T16 was tested by <a href="/wiki/S%C3%A9bastien_Loeb" title="Sébastien Loeb">Sébastien Loeb</a> at <a href="/wiki/Mont_Ventoux" title="Mont Ventoux">Mont Ventoux</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Loosely based on the shape and design of the production 208, the T16 is a lightweight 875&#160;kg (1,929&#160;lb) vehicle that uses the rear wing from the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_908" title="Peugeot 908">Peugeot 908</a>, and has a 3.2-litre, twin-turbo V6 engine, developing 875&#160;bhp (652&#160;kW; 887&#160;PS) with the aim of competing at the <a href="/wiki/Pikes_Peak_International_Hill_Climb" title="Pikes Peak International Hill Climb">Pikes Peak International Hill Climb</a>. 30 June 2013 saw this car demolish the standing record on Pikes Peak by over a minute and a half, with an overall time of 8:13.878.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup></p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Formula_One">Formula One</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Formula One">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<p>The company has also been involved in providing engines to <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> teams, notably to <a href="/wiki/McLaren_(racing)" class="mw-redirect" title="McLaren (racing)">McLaren</a> in <a href="/wiki/1994_Formula_One_season" title="1994 Formula One season">1994</a>, to <a href="/wiki/Jordan_Grand_Prix" title="Jordan Grand Prix">Jordan</a> for the <a href="/wiki/1995_Formula_One_season" title="1995 Formula One season">1995</a>, <a href="/wiki/1996_Formula_One_season" title="1996 Formula One season">1996</a> and <a href="/wiki/1997_Formula_One_season" title="1997 Formula One season">1997 seasons</a>, and to <a href="/wiki/Prost_(racing_team)" class="mw-redirect" title="Prost (racing team)">Prost</a> for the <a href="/wiki/1998_Formula_One_season" title="1998 Formula One season">1998</a>, <a href="/wiki/1999_Formula_One_season" title="1999 Formula One season">1999</a> and <a href="/wiki/2000_Formula_One_season" title="2000 Formula One season">2000 seasons</a>. The manufacturer did not score any victories, and their F1 interests were sold to <a href="/wiki/Asiatech" title="Asiatech">Asiatech</a> at the end of the 2000 season.</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Concept_cars">Concept cars</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: Concept cars">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Motorcycles">Motorcycles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: Motorcycles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Motorcycles" title="Peugeot Motorcycles">Peugeot Motorcycles</a></div>
<p>Peugeot Motorcycles company remains a major producer of <a href="/wiki/Scooter_(motorcycle)" title="Scooter (motorcycle)">scooters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Underbone" title="Underbone">underbones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moped" title="Moped">mopeds</a>, and bicycles in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> Peugeot produced an electric motor scooter, the <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_Scoot%27Elec" title="Peugeot Scoot'Elec">Peugeot Scoot'Elec</a>, from 1996 to 2006, and is projected to re-enter the market in 2011 with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=E-Vivacity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="E-Vivacity (page does not exist)">E-Vivacity</a>.</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-traditional">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
<div style="width: 155px">
<div class="thumb" style="width: 150px;">
<div style="margin:15px auto;"><a href="/wiki/File:Peugeot_Elys%C3%A9o_125,_Sondermodell_%27Roland_Garros%27_(2002).JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Peugeot_Elys%C3%A9o_125%2C_Sondermodell_%27Roland_Garros%27_%282002%29.JPG/80px-Peugeot_Elys%C3%A9o_125%2C_Sondermodell_%27Roland_Garros%27_%282002%29.JPG" width="80" height="120" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Peugeot_Elys%C3%A9o_125%2C_Sondermodell_%27Roland_Garros%27_%282002%29.JPG/120px-Peugeot_Elys%C3%A9o_125%2C_Sondermodell_%27Roland_Garros%27_%282002%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Peugeot_Elys%C3%A9o_125%2C_Sondermodell_%27Roland_Garros%27_%282002%29.JPG/160px-Peugeot_Elys%C3%A9o_125%2C_Sondermodell_%27Roland_Garros%27_%282002%29.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1629" data-file-height="2443" /></a></div>
</div>
<div class="gallerytext">
<p>Peugeot Elyséo 125, 'Roland Garros' (2002)</p>
</div>
</div>
</li>
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 155px">
<div style="width: 155px">

<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bicycles">Bicycles</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: Bicycles">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
<div role="note" class="hatnote">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Peugeot_(bicycles)" class="mw-redirect" title="Peugeot (bicycles)">Peugeot (bicycles)</a></div>
<p>Peugeot also produced bicycles starting in 1882 in Beaulieu, France (with ten <a href="/wiki/Tour_de_France" title="Tour de France">Tour de France</a> wins between 1903 and 1983), followed by motorcycles and cars in 1889. In the late 1980s Peugeot sold the North American rights to the Peugeot bicycle name to ProCycle, a Canadian company which also sold bicycles under the CCM and Velo Sport names.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> The European rights were briefly sold to Cycleurope S.A., returning to Peugeot in the 1990s.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup></p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Peugeot_Avenue">Peugeot Avenue</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Peugeot&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: Peugeot Avenue">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2>
<p>Peugeot has flagship dealerships, named Peugeot Avenue, located on the <a href="/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es" title="Champs-Élysées">Champs-Élysées</a> in <a href="/wiki/Paris" title="Paris">Paris</a>, and in <a href="/wiki/Berlin" title="Berlin">Berlin</a>. The Berlin showroom is larger than the Paris one, but both feature regularly changing mini-exhibitions displaying production and concept cars. Both also feature a small Peugeot Boutique, and they are popular places for Peugeot fans to visit. Peugeot Avenue Berlin also features a café, called Café de France. The Peugeot Avenue at Berlin closed in 2009.</p>

<li id="cite_note-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-52">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a rel="nofollow" class="external free" href="http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/auto/news/two-wheelers/motorcycles/mahindra-completes-51-stake-acquisition-in-peugeot-motocycles/articleshow/45956492.cms">http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/auto/news/two-wheelers/motorcycles/mahindra-completes-51-stake-acquisition-in-peugeot-motocycles/articleshow/45956492.cms</a></span></li>
